awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Construction of Risks and Remedies in Food Allergy Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Under the supervision of Prof. Michael Lynch, Ph.D. candidate Danya Glabau will  conduct ethnographic research to understand how people with food allergies, patient advocacy organization staff, and physicians conceive of "safety" for food allergic people and how they use treatment technologies to manage the risks to life posed by the illness. The co-PI will conduct semi-structured interviews with members of these three groups, observation of biomedical allergy treatment, participant observation in an online food allergy support community, and participant observation at three allergy-related conferences, to learn how patients understand and deploy three treatment strategies:  epinephrine injections, immunotherapy, and elimination diets.

The broader impacts of this project include improved communication between clinicians and patients and important contributions to the clinical literature on allergy. The most efficacious treatment strategy, eliminating allergenic foods from the diet of allergic people, requires both individual and collective actions. The individual must take care to avoid foods they are allergic to; but this is only possible if food manufacturers uniformly and consistently disclose ingredients and processing conditions on food labels and if there are mechanisms by which to exclude allergens from public spaces. Understanding what individual and collective measures would most effectively safeguard the health of Americans with chronic conditions is important. By amplifying patient voices, this project will offer a platform for a relatively common but often overlooked patient constituency to contribute to identification of new approaches.  The co PI will also identify existing weaknesses of food allergy treatment strategies and communicate these to the life science entrepreneurship community in the hopes of fostering collaborations that might lead to advances in nutrition substitutes or food processing methods that are healthy, palatable, and safe for people with food allergies who otherwise struggle to maintain a balanced diet.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to use ethnographic research methods (including participant observation, virtual ethnography, and semi-structured interviews) to investigate food allergy research and activism in the contemporary United States. More specifically, this project seeks to better understand how patient support groups, patients, and physicians think about the dangers posed by having a food allergy, and how those ideas shape healthcare decision-making and patient advocacy. The research focused in particular on how ideas about safety and danger influenced the use of elimination diets and injectable epinephrine in emergency situations. This grant provided funding for the Co-PI, Cornell University Science and Technology Studies (STS) PhD Candidate Danya Glabau, to attend four food allergy-related conferences during the July 2014 - June 2015 fiscal year.  A fifth trip occurred in November 2015, for which a no-cost, one-year extension was granted. Due to careful budgetary management, 5 research trips were completed rather than the three trips originally proposed.

The Co-PI’s dissertation based on this research argues that medical care is deeply shaped by moral judgments about what constitutes “good” medical care, even when that care uses the tools of scientific biomedicine (or “Western” medicine). Concerns about how best to take care of someone with food allergies are motivated both by a sense of urgency that immediate action may need to be taken to save the life of an allergic person and aspirations about how one can live with the condition and still fully participate in social and political life. Food allergy advocates are important players. Through their work, they are expanding who can act as a responsible caretaker beyond the circle of the nuclear family, enlisting educators, policymakers, and the public to the effort through activism and legislation. As healthcare in so-called developed countries shifts away from the treatment of infectious disease and toward the management of long-term and “lifestyle” disorders, this style of patient activism and the vision of society as a network of supportive communities will become a more prominent fixture in debates about how to care for chronically ill and disabled populations.

This was a Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant, and one important outcome of this award was that the Co-PI Danya Glabau, whose research was supported by the grant, successfully completed and defended her dissertation, in the Department of Science & Technology Studies Graduate Field.  The dissertation was titled, Morality in Action: Risking Death and Caring for Life in American Food Allergy Worlds.  Her PhD was awarded in May 2016, and she is now on the Faculty at the Brooklyn Institute for Social Research, and starting in January 2017 will be a Visiting Research Scholar at the CUNY Graduate Center.
